workflow.name: Schedule Firmware Upgrade for Networks by Tag
workflow.title: Schedule Firmware Upgrade for Networks by Tag

properties.name: Appliance Version ID to Upgrade
properties.description:
The Version ID is a unique identifier for a specific firmware version in the Cisco Meraki system. Leave the field empty to skip scheduling the product type.

To find the available Version IDs for your network, use the "Check Available Firmware for Network" workflow.

Example: 4532 might correspond to firmware version MX 15.1.1.

properties.name: Network Tags to Search
properties.description:
Provide a list of network tags to search. Only networks in the user's organization with at least one matching tag from this list will be included. Note: The filtering is case-sensitive.
Example:
[
  "example-tag", "another-tag"
]

properties.name: Wireless Version ID to Upgrade
properties.description:
The Version ID is a unique identifier for a specific firmware version in the Cisco Meraki system. Leave the field empty to skip scheduling the product type.

To find the available Version IDs for your network, use the "Check Available Firmware for Network" workflow.

Example: 4532 might correspond to firmware version MR 15.1.1.

properties.name: Switch Version ID to Upgrade
properties.description:
The Version ID is a unique identifier for a specific firmware version in the Cisco Meraki system. Leave the field empty to skip scheduling the product type.

To find the available Version IDs for your network, use the "Check Available Firmware for Network" workflow.

Example: 4531 might correspond to firmware version MS 15.1.1.

properties.name: Result
properties.description: Comprehensive summary of firmware upgrade scheduling results, including successful and failed network upgrades with detailed information.

properties.name: Status Code
properties.description: The HTTP status code of the workflow execution.

properties.name: Temp Message
properties.description: Temporary variable used to accumulate and format output messages from multiple network processing operations.

properties.name: Error Message
properties.description: The error message if the workflow fails.

properties.name: Status Message
properties.description: The status message of the workflow execution.

properties.name: Upgrade Date Time
properties.description:
The date and time for the next firmware upgrade in the network. The upgrade for network devices is scheduled using the network's timezone to ensure they get the latest updates. If no date-time is given, it will be set to the next 5 minutes. The upgrade can be scheduled up to 1 month from today, and all devices will use the same date and time. 
Example: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS

This workflow allows users to schedule firmware upgrades for one or more networks based on input tags. The workflow first identifies networks that have the input tags, then queries networks across organizations that the user has access to.

The workflow currently provides firmware upgrade options for Appliance, Switch, and Wireless devices in the network. All networks are upgraded on the same date and time.

Prerequisites:
- User must have network admin privileges for target organizations
- Target networks must exist and have the specified tags

Limitations:
- Maximum 500 networks per organization query
- Upgrades scheduled for same date/time across all networks
- Case-sensitive tag matching
- Requires existing firmware version IDs
properties.display_name: Schedule Firmware Upgrade for Networks by Tag

else:
    isValid = True
    errorMessage = ""

properties.description: Validate upgrade date format when a custom date is provided.
Check if upgrade date time is provided and in correct format (YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS)
Execute date format validation when a custom upgrade date/time is provided by the user.
Validates the upgrade date time format. Accepts empty value or 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS' format.
properties.script:
import re
import sys
from datetime import datetime

# Get the date time input
(upgrade_datetime,) = sys.argv[1:2]

# Initialize validation result
valid_date = True
error_message = ''

# Check if date is empty (which is allowed)
if not upgrade_datetime or upgrade_datetime.strip() == '':
    valid_date = True
    error_message = ''
else:
    # Validate the format using regex: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS
    date_pattern = r'^\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2} \d{2}:\d{2}:\d{2}$'
    
    if not re.match(date_pattern, upgrade_datetime):
        valid_date = False
        error_message = f'Invalid date format: "{upgrade_datetime}". Expected format: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS (e.g., 2025-05-20 14:30:00)'
    else:
        # Additional validation - try to parse the date to ensure it's a valid date
        try:
            datetime.strptime(upgrade_datetime, '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
            valid_date = True
            error_message = ''
        except ValueError:
            valid_date = False
            error_message = f'Invalid date values: "{upgrade_datetime}". Please check month, day, hour, minute, and second values are valid.'

properties.script:
import re
import sys

# Note: When you have one item as input you need extra comma - it's not a mistake
(input_text, mxID, msID, mrID, dtime, tagsArr) = sys.argv[1:7]

# If dtime is empty, set as text "5 minutes from now"
if not dtime:
    dtime = "5 minutes from now"

# If tagsArr should be a string, keep as is. If you expect a list, split by comma:
# tagsArr = tagsArr.split(",") if tagsArr else []

# Summary information 
summary_info = {
    "time_date": dtime,
    "appliance_version": mxID, 
    "switch_version": msID,  
    "wireless_version": mrID,
    "tags": tagsArr
}

def parse_meraki_output(text):
    results = {
        "scheduled_upgrades": [],
        "failed_upgrades": [],
        "no_matching_tags": []
    }

    current_organization = None
    lines = text.splitlines()

    for line in lines:
        if line.startswith("Results for Organization:"):
            # Extract current organization name
            current_organization = line.split("Results for Organization:")[1].strip()
        elif line.startswith("Network:") and "upgrade is scheduled" in line:
            # Extract scheduled network name
            network_name = re.search(r"Network:\s(.+?)\supgrade is scheduled", line)
            if network_name:
                results["scheduled_upgrades"].append({
                    "organization": current_organization,
                    "network": network_name.group(1)
                })
        elif line.startswith("Network:") and "upgrade failed to schedule" in line:
            # Extract failed network name and reason
            failed_match = re.search(r"Network:\s(.+?)\supgrade failed to schedule\.(.+)", line)
            if failed_match:
                results["failed_upgrades"].append({
                    "organization": current_organization,
                    "network": failed_match.group(1),
                    "reason": failed_match.group(2).strip("[]")
                })
        elif re.match(r"Organization: .+ has no matching tags\.", line):
            # Extract organization name and add to no_matching_tags
            org_match = re.match(r"Organization:\s(.+)\shas no matching tags\.", line)
            if org_match:
                org_name = org_match.group(1).strip()
                results["no_matching_tags"].append(org_name)

    return results

def display_results(results, summary_info):
    sys.stdout.write("Network Firmware Schedule Output Summary:")
    sys.stdout.write(f"Schedule Time/Date: {summary_info['time_date']}")
    sys.stdout.write(f"Upgrade to Appliance version: {summary_info['appliance_version']}")
    sys.stdout.write(f"Upgrade to Switch version: {summary_info['switch_version']}")
    sys.stdout.write(f"Upgrade to Wireless version: {summary_info['wireless_version']}")
    sys.stdout.write(f"Matched Tags: {summary_info['tags']}\n")

    if results["scheduled_upgrades"]:
        sys.stdout.write("Successfully Scheduled Firmware for: Organization Name - Network Name\n")
        for item in results["scheduled_upgrades"]:
            organization = item['organization'].strip()
            network = item['network'].strip()
            sys.stdout.write(f"{organization} - {network}")
        sys.stdout.write("\n")

    if results["failed_upgrades"]:
        sys.stdout.write("Failed to Schedule Firmware for: Organization Name - Network Name - Failure Reason\n")
        for item in results["failed_upgrades"]:
            organization = item['organization'].strip()
            network = item['network'].strip()
            reason = item['reason'].strip()
            sys.stdout.write(f"{organization} - {network} - {reason}")
        sys.stdout.write("\n")

    # Section for Organizations with No Matching Tags
    if results.get("no_matching_tags"):
        sys.stdout.write("No Tags match in Organizations:\n")
        for org in results["no_matching_tags"]:
            sys.stdout.write(f"{org}")
        sys.stdout.write("\n")

# Parse and display results
results = parse_meraki_output(input_text)
display_results(results, summary_info)

properties.description: Set the final output variables with workflow execution results, including the formatted summary, status indicators, and error information.

properties.name: Wireless Version ID to Upgrade
properties.description: Specific firmware version ID for Meraki Wireless Access Points (MR) devices to upgrade to. This must be a valid version ID available for the wireless devices in your network. Use the 'Check Available Firmware for Network' workflow to identify compatible version IDs. Leave empty to use the latest available firmware version. Example: 4952 for MR firmware v29.7.

properties.name: Ignore Errors
properties.description: Controls workflow behavior when encountering API errors or validation failures. When set to false (default), the workflow will terminate on first error with detailed error information. When set to true, the workflow continues processing and provides best-effort results despite errors.

properties.name: Organization ID or Name
properties.description: Meraki organization identifier - provide either the organization name (e.g., 'Acme Corporation') or the organization ID (e.g., '123456'). The workflow automatically detects the input type and resolves to the correct organization ID. Organization names are case-sensitive and must match exactly as they appear in the Meraki Dashboard.

properties.name: Appliance Version ID to Upgrade
properties.description: Specific firmware version ID for Meraki Security Appliance (MX) devices to upgrade to. This must be a valid version ID available for the appliances in your network. Use the 'Check Available Firmware for Network' workflow to identify compatible version IDs. Leave empty to use the latest available firmware version. Example: 4727 for MX firmware v18.107.2.

properties.name: Status Code
properties.description: HTTP status code indicating the firmware upgrade scheduling operation result. Returns 200 for successful scheduling, 404 for network/organization not found, 400 for invalid parameters, and other standard HTTP codes for various error conditions. Essential for automated workflow decision-making.

properties.name: Upgrade Date Time
properties.description: Scheduled date and time for the firmware upgrade in 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS' format using the network's timezone. All devices in the network will be upgraded simultaneously at this time. If left empty, the upgrade will be scheduled for 5 minutes from now. Maximum scheduling window is 30 days from current date. Examples: '2025-05-20 14:30:00' for 2:30 PM on May 20th, '2025-12-15 02:00:00' for 2:00 AM maintenance window.

properties.name: Status Message
properties.description: Human-readable status message describing the firmware upgrade scheduling operation outcome. Provides clear success confirmation, partial completion details, or failure reasons. Essential for user feedback and workflow orchestration decision-making in automated deployments.

properties.name: Error Message
properties.description: Detailed error information when firmware upgrade scheduling fails. Contains specific API error messages, validation failures, or system issues to enable effective troubleshooting. Empty when workflow completes successfully, populated with diagnostic details when errors occur.

properties.name: Result
properties.description: Complete JSON response from the Meraki Dashboard API containing detailed firmware upgrade scheduling results. Includes upgrade confirmation details, scheduled times, affected devices, and any warnings or additional information returned by the API for troubleshooting and audit purposes.

properties.name: Switch Version ID to Upgrade
properties.description: Specific firmware version ID for Meraki Switch (MS) devices to upgrade to. This must be a valid version ID available for the switches in your network. Use the 'Check Available Firmware for Network' workflow to identify compatible version IDs. Leave empty to use the latest available firmware version. Example: 4758 for MS firmware v15.21.1.

properties.name: Local Organization ID
properties.description: Internal variable that stores the resolved Meraki organization ID after processing the input (organization name or ID). This variable ensures consistent organization identification throughout the workflow regardless of input format.

properties.name: Network Name
properties.description: The exact name of the Meraki network where firmware upgrades will be scheduled. Must match an existing network within the specified organization. Network names are case-sensitive and must be provided exactly as they appear in the Meraki Dashboard.

Schedules firmware upgrades for Meraki network devices including Security Appliances (MX), Switches (MS), and Wireless Access Points (MR). Accepts organization name or ID, locates the specified network, and schedules firmware upgrades with specified version IDs and timing. Supports flexible scheduling from immediate (5 minutes) to 30 days in advance using network timezone. 

Automatically compares current firmware versions against target versions and only schedules upgrades when necessary. Multiple executions are safe - devices already running target versions are skipped with clear status reporting.

Use 'Check Available Firmware for Network' workflow first to identify compatible firmware version IDs.
Validates firmware version ID inputs and provides helpful feedback if all version inputs are empty.

Performs comprehensive input validation using parallel execution for improved performance. Three validation types run simultaneously: version ID input validation, upgrade date/time format validation, and firmware version ID format verification. This parallel approach reduces total validation time while ensuring all inputs meet required standards before proceeding with firmware upgrade operations.

Validates that at least one firmware version ID is provided for any device type (appliance, switch, or wireless). This validation runs in parallel with other input checks to improve workflow performance.
Check if all firmware version ID inputs are empty and provide guidance if needed
All firmware version IDs are empty - provide guidance

properties.description: Validates firmware version IDs for all device types (appliance, switch, wireless) to ensure they are numeric when provided (e.g., 4727, 4952, 4758). Empty values are allowed to skip upgrades for specific device types. This validation runs in parallel with other input checks.
Validates that version IDs are numeric when provided
properties.script:
import re
import sys

# Get version IDs from command line arguments
(appliance_version, switch_version, wireless_version) = sys.argv[1:4]

# Initialize validation result
valid_versions = True
error_messages = []

# Function to validate version ID format
def validate_version_id(version_id, device_type):
    if not version_id or version_id.strip() == '':
        return True, ''  # Empty is allowed
    
    # Check if it's numeric
    if not version_id.isdigit():
        return False, f'Invalid {device_type} Version ID: "{version_id}". Version IDs must be numeric (e.g., 4727, 4952, 4758).'
    
    return True, ''

# Validate each version ID
validations = [
    (appliance_version, 'Appliance'),
    (switch_version, 'Switch'),
    (wireless_version, 'Wireless')
]

for version_id, device_type in validations:
    is_valid, error_msg = validate_version_id(version_id, device_type)
    if not is_valid:
        valid_versions = False
        error_messages.append(error_msg)

# Combine error messages
final_error_message = '\n'.join(error_messages) if error_messages else ''

properties.description: Check if version ID validation failed and exit with error if invalid format
Version ID format validation failed

properties.description: Completed action
Processes firmware data to remove current versions from available upgrade lists and filter unnecessary attributes.
properties.script:
import sys
import json

####################
# This section establishes some inputs and local variables we need for later
####################

# Note when you have one item as input you need extra comma - it's not a mistake
(mxDetails,msDetails,mrDetails) = sys.argv[1:4]

def remove_current_version_and_attributes(json_data):
    """
    Removes the current version from the list of available versions and
    excludes 'releaseDate' and 'firmware' attributes from the output JSON.
    Handles missing/empty device types gracefully.

    Parameters:
    json_data (str): The JSON data as a string.

    Returns:
    tuple: (updated_json_str, no_available_versions_flag)
        - updated_json_str: The updated JSON data as a string or appropriate message for missing devices
        - no_available_versions_flag: Boolean indicating if current version is the only available version
    """
    # Handle null, empty, or invalid inputs
    if not json_data or json_data == 'null' or json_data.strip() == '' or json_data == 'None':
        return "No devices of this type found in the network.", False
    
    try:
        # Parse the JSON string into a Python dictionary
        data = json.loads(json_data)
        
        # Handle empty or null parsed data
        if not data or data is None:
            return "No devices of this type found in the network.", False
        
        # Check if required keys exist
        if 'currentVersion' not in data or not data['currentVersion']:
            return "No current version information available for this device type.", False
        
        if 'id' not in data['currentVersion']:
            return "Invalid current version data for this device type.", False
        
        # Find the current version ID
        current_version_id = data['currentVersion']['id']
        
        # Handle missing availableVersions key
        if 'availableVersions' not in data:
            data['availableVersions'] = []
        
        # Check if current version is the only available version
        available_version_ids = [version.get('id') for version in data['availableVersions'] if version.get('id')]
        no_available_versions = len(available_version_ids) == 1 and current_version_id in available_version_ids
        
        # Remove the current version and filter out specific attributes
        data['availableVersions'] = [
            # iterate over each element in available versions and remove extra elements
            {key: version[key] for key in version if key not in ['releaseDate', 'firmware']}
            for version in data['availableVersions']
            if version.get('id') != current_version_id
        ]
        
        # Remove from final JSON (safely handle missing keys)
        data.pop('currentVersion', None)
        data.pop('lastUpgrade', None)
        data.pop('nextUpgrade', None)
        data.pop('isUpgradeAvailable', None)
        data.pop('participateInNextBetaRelease', None)
        
        # Check if 'availableVersions' is an empty list
        if not data['availableVersions']:
            return "Running the latest firmware.", no_available_versions
        else:
            # Keep the original data if not empty
            # Return the updated JSON data as a string
            return json.dumps(data, indent=4), no_available_versions
            
    except json.JSONDecodeError:
        return "Invalid JSON data for this device type.", False
    except KeyError as e:
        return f"Missing required data field: {str(e)}", False
    except Exception as e:
        return f"Error processing device data: {str(e)}", False

# Process each device type and capture both JSON and boolean results
applianceResult, applianceNoVersions = remove_current_version_and_attributes(mxDetails)
switchResult, switchNoVersions = remove_current_version_and_attributes(msDetails)
wirelessResult, wirelessNoVersions = remove_current_version_and_attributes(mrDetails)

# Set the JSON results for backward compatibility
applianceAvailableVersionsJson = applianceResult
switchAvailableVersionsJson = switchResult
wirelessAvailableVersionsJson = wirelessResult

# Set individual boolean flags for each product type (using positive logic)
# True = upgrades available, False = no upgrades available
applianceHasUpgradeAvailable = not applianceNoVersions
switchHasUpgradeAvailable = not switchNoVersions
wirelessHasUpgradeAvailable = not wirelessNoVersions
